Posts.Title: Radiation & Tattoos JFfromTN yizbieta

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2008 09:41AM lisettemac wrote: I can understand why you're nervous.  Be sure to tell the radiologist that the lumps haven't changed with your cycles. My radiologist did a biopsy right then and there ... but he told me that he is only able to do it that way because he doesn't accept insurance.  He said that many insurance companies will not allow for an u/s, additional views or biopsy to be done on the same day as the mammo because they fear that they will be ordered "as a matter of course" rather than in response to what is seen on the first image.  So, don't be concerned if you can't get a biopsy today, but be sure to get one scheduled if it seems advisable to have one. Best to you.
Posts.Title: Doctors appointment today cemjo3 lisettemac

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2008 12:59PM lisettemac wrote: Count me in the weight gainer group.  Not 20 lbs, but about 10-12.  My Onc says most people do and he asked for my perspective on why.  I think it would be easy to point to the steroids, but in my case, that would be taking the easy way out.  Like NatsFan, I worked full-time through my treatment and also have a young family.  It took everything out of me.  I simply didn't have the energy to work out and I didn't.  I also had a lot of nausea during treatment.  As I told the dr, the last thing you want when you're nauseous is a crunchy salad!  So, I also indulged myself in more carbs, higher fat foods, etc.  It adds up.  But I decided I could only really focus on one thing at a time and I cut myself some slack on the diet and exercise.  Of course, now it's time to get that extra weight off.
Posts.Title: weight gain during chemo??? rayhope theprettiestmess

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2008 12:08PM - edited Nov 26, 2008 12:09PM by lisettemac Hi Zuffa: I agree with the others that it is important to listen to your body and how you feel and take it all as it comes. I had my chemo at 40.  I am an employment lawyer at a big company that was doing lots of layoffs last year during my chemo -- so pretty stressful and requiring me to make lots of decisions.  I got 4 AC and 4 Taxol, dose dense.  I scheduled my chemo on Thursdays, with a shot of Neulasta (or something like that) on Fridays.  I usually took my chemo day itself off, but no other days regularly off.  I had quite a bit of nausea -- about 10 days between treatments.  I also had severe reflux during the Taxol treatments.  My blood counts remained generally good which kept my energy level up. For me (and it isn't the right answer for everyone), working helped me feel "normal."  I didn't want the breast cancer to define me and I didn't want to sit at home and feel sorry for myself.  Looking back on it, I can see that there were days when I felt pretty glassy-eyed and had trouble focusing.  I think this was largely due to the anti-nauseals I was taking (Ativan, among others), rather than the chemo itself.  A short leave might have been a good idea.  But selfishly, I didn't want to do it. My onc would repeat the same mantra to me week in and week out:  do what you feel like doing.  If you feel up to going out to dinner or working, do it.  If you feel up to a visit from family, do it.  Of course, he always followed this with the 3 things that (I can only guess) *he* likes to do -- "go to the movies, drink wine, have sex!"  LOL. So, if you feel like continuing to work feels "right" to you, do it.  But don't be afraid to take a little time to yourself, too.  Sometimes 1 day at home is worth 3 in the office.
Posts.Title: Working During Chemo zuffa kjbell

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2009 05:32PM lisettemac wrote: Well, I had a similar diagnosis (from what I can understand).  I was stage 1, 1.1 cm, no lymph node involvement, grade 3, HER-2/neu+, ER+. I specifically asked the surgeon if there was any reason to consider a mastectomy in my case and she said no.  She said the outcome for my dx was the same for mastectomy as it was for lumpectomy and radiation. That being said, this can be a decision about how you want to approach this and how you feel about your breasts.  You may be able to avoid the radiation if you do a mastectomy vs. lumpectomy -- does that matter to you?  Where is the lump and how large are your breasts?  Some drs recommend a mastectomy if a lumpectomy in your situation would result in not much breast left.
Posts.Title: Am I choosing the right treatment? ssimmons66 achen2iron

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2010 01:39AM lisettemac wrote: Knowledge is indeed power.  Good for you all for asking questions and insisting on getting the answers.  It is also important to check that screen and be sure that the patient info matches your name, etc. I also had IMRT on a Valerian machine.  What makes me mad (still mad about it, in fact) is that the radiation onc basically refused to answer my questions about radiation.  He said to me, "well, what do you want to know?"  When I said that I didn't know anything about how it worked, the risks, etc, he just kind of laughed and said "some people want to audit the course and some people just want to show up and do what the dr tells them to do .... which one are you?" I was so upset and frightened during the testing/set-up, but I chalked it up to being tired from chemo.   I should have trusted my instincts and insisted that he run me through the basics, including why IMRT is so much better. So don't stop ladies until you get the information you need.
Posts.Title: Frightening NYT article on radiation TX pj12 MAGOB

Posts.Content: lisettemac wrote: Anyone see this article in the NYTimes about a new study finding that a shorter course of radiation therapy could be just as effective as the current standard of care?  The article also talks about positioning women on their stomachs (rather than backs) during radiation in order to limit the amount of radiation going to heart/lungs. http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/23/health/research/23canc.html?_r=1&8dpc&oref=slogin Did anyone who got radiation to their left breast use this positioning?  I wish my radiation onc had done this since I also got A/C chemo and herceptin -- both of which can cause heart damage. Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2007 06:57AM lisettemac wrote: Hi Katz: In addition to the Oncotype, you might ask your Onc if he consulted Adjuvant Online. It's an online system where he can input the characteristics of your cancer and get information about the benefits of different therapies (chemo, radiation, tamoxifen, etc). My dr did it and shared the data with us. I had a high oncotype score, so chemo was indicated, but just seeing how much of a difference each therapy would make was helpful in making a decision, too. While each one only knocked off a small percentage of recurrence, it was important to us to get my recurrence rate down to the single digits. DH is a big "numbers guy" so it really helped him to see the data. You might ask about this. Best wishes to you in deciding what treatment to get.
